lexUnit.name: freeze.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: (with reference to a liquid) turn or be turned into ice or another solid as a result of extreme cold.

sentence.text: Notices warning of the dangers of thin ice were put up in the last few days when the lake froze over .
Arctic ponds and lakes freeze to depths of 1-2.5 m from September onward , and accumulate a layer of compacted snow on top of the ice during winter .
The lake rarely freezes so we have little opportunity to discover our ice-legs .
The river Thames in London froze right up to Westminster .
They do n't know about cold so intense that rivers freeze over so you can drive a horse and cart across them .
Inside , the water in one of the bathrooms froze .
Standing water will also freeze in winter -- an obvious but often forgotten hazard .
The man slept on the floor , and the water that had been spilt froze on the floor .
Those in smaller ponds must experience much lower temperatures when the water about them freezes .
Common salt and water form a cryohydrate which freezes at -21.2Â°C .
Everything in the house froze solid -- the water in the kettle , even my false teeth in a cup beside my bed .
There were nights when stone hot-water bottles left out on the floor froze solid .
Container-grown evergreens , such as bays ( Laurus nobilis ) are especially vulnerable because the root-ball may freeze solid .
Beneath the boards on which the men squatted the matter froze hard and solid .
After two weeks it started snowing and the ground froze .
They sprayed cold water on my dog when it was snowing and all her fur froze .
The ice made a crackling sound now as it froze harder and the wipers shifted it .
This year it froze right through and they all spent the afternoon of Christmas Eve sliding on it .
Disappointingly strawberries do not freeze so if you do not eat them at once you need to use them up in some other way .
Unused buttercream will freeze well until needed .
Garlic does n't freeze well , so do n't keep any cooked dish containing garlic too long .
